awd_titl_txt: Division plane orientation in plant cells.
awd_abstract_narration:
This research improves the public well-being through development of critical knowledge using the important crop maize and other plants to understand cell division and its role in development. A critical aspect of cell division is the orientation of the division plane or the axis at which division occurs. When and where the cell positions the division plane has significant impact on the overall organization of the plant. Although the importance of regulated division plane orientation during plant and animal development is well known, the mechanisms that controls this process are not well understood. Understanding how plants regulate division plane orientation will make it possible to harness this feature of plant development for next generation crop improvement.  Broader Impact activities will include providing a research experience to freshman students along with research opportunities to underrepresented minority students. 

Correct division plane orientation, or the establishment of the axis on which a cell divides, is critical for development and growth in many organisms. This research will determine the biochemical and in vivo function of proteins responsible for controlling division plane orientation in the monocot crop maize. The experimental approaches include single-molecule protein and microtubule dynamics, live cell imaging, structure versus function analysis, mathematical modeling, and reverse and forward genetics. The expected outcome of this research is an understanding as to how a protein essential for division plane orientation alters microtubule binding and dynamics, identification of amino acids critical for this protein's function, as well as quantification of the relative contributions of cell shape and local and global interactions to division plane orientation. Finally, new proteins will be identified that promote the proper division plane orientation. Understanding how plants place their division planes may provide insight into controlling division orientation to increase yield of valuable crop plant products.

Project Outcomes Report

Over 70 percent of all biomass on the planet originates from plants, and plants are the primary source of food for humans and animals. Plant cell division is an essential part of plant growth and development, and understanding the process may lead to future improvements in crop yield. Research from the Rasmussen lab has led to several groundbreaking discoveries in understanding how plant cells divide, including publication of ten peer-reviewed papers during this NSF-funded project. In addition, this project has trained undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral fellows and engaged in outreach with elementary school students.

Major Scientific Discoveries

Plant cell division is influenced by neighboring cells

Observations of the majority of plant cell divisions indicate that the cell is evenly divided into two daughter cells. The new cell wall is formed in a location that provides the shortest path to minimize the amount of materials required. In our collaborative study, we developed a mathematical model to predict how cells will divide based solely on the geometry of the cells. Those predicted divisions, which identify the shortest paths, were compared to real plant cell divisions and real animal cell divisions. The majority of animal and plant cell divisions tended to follow predictions, indicating that geometry of the cell is often the most important factor in forming the division plane. However, we discovered that plant cell divisions will deviate from the predicted divisions under specific conditions. If the nearby cell has a wall that is parallel to the predicted division, the division will shift away from the shortest path. This indicates that plant cell division patterns are influenced by nearby cells, therefore forming plant tissues that are likely more mechanically stable.

Division plane positioning requires two unrelated plant proteins

How plant cell division is positioned is important for proper formation of the plant body. In our collaborative study, we showed that two unrelated plant proteins, called AUXIN INDUCED IN ROOT CULTURES9 (AIR9) and TANGLED1 (TAN1) are required for division positioning in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. These proteins, which interact with filaments required for cell division and cell elongation called microtubules, play a critical role in division positioning. These proteins both localize to the future plane of division. When neither protein is present in cells, division positioning is affected: plant cell divisions often no longer follow the shortest paths. We showed that different domains within the TAN1 protein were required for proper cell divisions together with AIR9. This provides important insight into how these microtubule-binding proteins function during plant cell division.

TAN1 protein mediates microtubule interactions 

Understanding how TAN1 interacts with microtubules is critical to understanding how it functions during plant cell division. In this collaborative study, we analyzed the properties of the TAN1 protein in a "test-tube". The TAN1 protein by itself binds to and bundles microtubules in an unusual way, by promoting transient interactions between microtubules at a wide variety of angles. In addition, the TAN1 protein binds to the subunits that generate microtubules, called tubulin dimers. This important "test tube" result led to the prediction that TAN1 transiently interacts with and stabilizes microtubules, which was consistent with its behavior in plant cells.

Broader Impacts

Undergraduate and graduate students, including underrepresented minority students, were trained during this project, including over one hundred University of California, Riverside first year biology students that participated in our research program during their introductory biology course. Past undergraduate and graduate students have gone to graduate school, won prestigious postdoctoral fellowships, and found science related jobs. Former members of the lab are active members of the STEM-trained workforce, an area of national need. In addition, members of the lab participated regularly in outreach by leading elementary school students through experiments that allowed them to look at cells in plant leaves and make predictions about how cells contribute to plant growth. Undergraduate and graduate students often answer questions about going to college and graduate school and are positive role models for future scientists during outreach events.
